required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Use of New Supraglottic Airway Devices in Severely Obese Patients: A Feasibility Study
clinical_study.official_title: Use of New Supraglottic Airway Devices in Severely Obese Patients: A Feasibility Study

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether two new airway devices used during anesthesia called iGEL™ and KING-LTS-DTM work well and are safe in obese patients. They both work well in thin patients, but have not been tested in obese patients.

clinical_study.why_stopped: No subjects enrolled. Funding withdrawn by sponsor.

primary_outcome.description: Oropharyngeal leak pressure in cm H2O for the duration of the case at 1, 15, 30, 60, 120 minutes.

secondary_outcome.measure: Difference in insertion time for one of the supraglottic airway devices
secondary_outcome.description: Effective airway time (time required to place the endotracheal tube/ supraglottic airway device).

arm_group.description: Subjects will receive an IGel(TM) airway induction and maintenance of positive pressure ventilation
Subject will receive a KING-LTS-D(TM) for induction and maintenance of positive pressure ventilation

intervention.description: iGEL(TM) airway will be used for induction and maintenance of positive pressure ventilation
KING-LTS-D(TM) airway will be used for induction and maintenance of positive pressure ventilation

reference.citation: Kheterpal S, Martin L, Shanks AM, Tremper KK. Prediction and outcomes of impossible mask ventilation: a review of 50,000 anesthetics. Anesthesiology. 2009 Apr;110(4):891-7. doi: 10.1097/ALN.0b013e31819b5b87.
